description.text:
String "Climbing" Christmas Tree is another string climber based on the dual spool design of this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1825987. It doesn't really climb the string, it just appears to do so.

Consisting of 9 unique parts (11 total), and only requiring the purchase of embroidery floss, once assembled String Climbing Christmas Tree puts to use the "String Climbing Mechanism" and further illustrates how string climbing toys such as these, some over 100 years old, operate.

Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n-LyBzluu74.

"Bling" added by my wife.

Designed using Sketchup Make 2016, sliced with Cura, and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 2 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used supports for "Star.stl".

Parts I Purchased:

1) Embroidery floss (super center, sewing shop, Amazon, etc). Sewing thread is too thin, and standard cotton string is too large and frays.

Printing:

Print 2 "Tower.stl" and "Ring.stl", then print 1 each of the remaining pieces.

Assembly:

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required. If the tight fitting components are too loose, add a small dot of cyanoacrylate to each side of the pin, allow to dry completely (I use accelerator to speed the process), then try the fit again. Repeat until tight.

Assemble as per "Assembly.stl". I perform the assembly task in the following order:

1) Press "Spool Center.stl" onto "Spool Large.stl".

2) Press "Spool Small.stl" onto "Spool Large.stl".

3) Press "Axle.stl" into "Spool Large.stl".

4) Cut two 24" lengths of embroidery floss, and tie a knot into one end of each piece.

5) Starting with the unknotted end, thread the embroidery floss into the small hole in "Spool Large.stl" starting from the flat side, then pull it all the way through until the knot sits inside the hole. Secure the knot in the hole using cyanoacrylate glue.

6) Repeat step 5 for "Spool Small.stl".

7) Wind the embroidery thread onto the spools in opposite directions. On the large spool, leave about 4" of embroidery thread unwound, the small spool about 10" of embroidery thread unwound.

8) Slide one axle into one of the "Tower.stl", then the other into the second "Tower.stl", then press the assembly into "Case.stl" making sure the short embroidery floss exits the hole in the bottom of "Case.stl", and the long embroidery floss exits the hole in the top of "Case.stl".

9) Insert the long embroidery floss into the bottom of "Star.stl", then slide "Star.stl" down the embroidery floss and press it into the top hole in "Case.stl".

10) Tie one "Ring.stl" to the embroidery thread from the large spool. I tied a double knot, secured the knot with cyanoacrylate glue, then trimmed away the excess. This ring is the "lower ring".

11) Tie the remaining "Ring.stl" to the thread from the small spool and secure and trim it as was done to the lower ring. This is the "upper ring".

12) Press "Lid.stl" onto "Case.stl" making sure the two towers fit into their respective holes.

13) Pick the entire assemble up by the rings, the upper ring on top. Pulling either ring will cause String Climbing Christmas Tree to climb the embroidery floss. Allowing the embroidery floss to go slack will allow gravity to return String Climbing Christmas Tree to the lower ring.

Hope you print one!

print_settings.Notes:: The side that the fan attaches to should lay flat on the print bed. Supports are only needed inside the hole for the AC inlet.
print_settings.Printer:: Monoprice Maker Select v2 (Wanhao Duplicator i3)

title: Wanhao i3 PSU Cover 120mm Fan Adapter

description.text:
An adapter that lets you mount a 120mm fan to the back of the control box / PSU of Wanhao Duplicator i3 (Monoprice Maker Select V2).This makes the control box quieter and keeps it cool during printing.

  • Version 1.1 (Nov-8-2016, Recommended version)
    • Thickened the tabs that hold the screws that bolt to the printer.
    • Enlarged bolt holes for AC inlet. However, I still recommend using mounting tape instead of bolts here.
    • There are 6 variations
      • SameSide - The hole for the tether is on the same side as the AC inlet
      • OppositeSide - The hole for the tether on the opposite side of the AC inlet
      • BothSides - The hole for the tether is on both sides. There is still only one hole for the AC inlet
      • Invert - The bottom of the adapter is curved instead of the top. The top is flat. For underslung control boxes.
    • If you want your AC inlet to be on the right instead of the left side, mirror the STLs in your slicer.
  • Version 1.0 (Old Version)
    • Initial version, kept here for reference
    • The bolt tabs are a bit weak. V1.1 is recommended.

The adapter mounts to the printer using the screws from the original metal back-plate.

The fan mounts by sliding in from the top, using it's screws as "hooks". You can adjust the tightness of the friction fit by adjusting the these screws. I used this attachment method because the included fan screws were not long enough to screw through the fan into the adapter.

On this adapter, both the tether to the rest of the printer and power cable exit from the left of the control box. There are screw holes to mount the power inlet. However, because the original machine screws did not bite into the printed plastic very well, I used exterior-grade mounting tape between the adapter and the power inlet mounting flanges instead. This turned out to be much more rigid than using two screws.

I installed the adapter using the hex wrenches that came with the printer. However, it was tedious because the wrenches are quite short. It became much easier when I used longer hex drivers.

The fan I used is from a Cooler Master Sleeve Bearing 120mm "Value 4-Pack", but any 120mm should have the same screw pattern.

Fan guard: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1595208

Onshape link: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/6458865d07317ea7421b5648/w/8fbe7f67ff219c54f2fa58fa/e/67c2db4929d27824efcfcbc0

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2 (Wanhao Duplicator i3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layers, 2 shells

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The side that the fan attaches to should lay flat on the print bed. Supports are only needed inside the hole for the AC inlet.

title: Zewa paper holder for OBI pegboards

description.text:
Hint: Only the two ends are printed!
The rod ist a normal plastic water rod rest from my cellar.

About my pegboard:
I have buyed a pegboard from OBI (
https://www.obi.de/lochwandsysteme/lochwand-mit-vierkantlochung-1200-mm-breit/p/9178419).

This pegboard has square perforations with 1cm^2. This squares has the advantage for us owner of 3d printers that you can build your own set of items directly out of the printer.
The normal pegboards are only drilled with 3mm holes, so you need metal hooks because the prints will break with that thickness.

I am offering a series of all my prints for this pegboard for using or inspiration of your own items.

Please think about the needed density of your prints when you are slicing!
i have used PLA with a density between 25 and 50% (often with support, some items you have to clue befor using them). A resolution of 0.2 mm should be enough for your pegboard-items.

author: richplatts

description.text: Nerjigal Savant space Helmet
This is a 4-Speed transmission modeled in under eight hours using SpaceClaim. There are a total of 50 parts.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15-20%

Introduction The purpose of transmission in a car is to convert the torque created by the engine into a larger amount of torque through gear ratios. This means that in a low gear, the engine spins faster, but there is a higher resultant force on the tires, meaning the vehicle is able to climb steep hills, accelerate faster, etc. In a high gear, the vehicle will move faster, but will have more trouble accelerating, especially on an incline.
Plan See instructions for details. Estimated time to completion: 1-2 weeks.
Materials This project will require a great deal of time, as well as multiple spools of filament.

comments.text:
You can use a program like Blender to cut the casing pieces in half, but you will need to use Boolean modifiers. Learn how to do this here:

I always get warping on the left side of my print bed and I am trying to narrow down where the problems are coming from and I think that the fans are actually cooling the left side of the bed more then the rest (their airflow is totally weird) and I am trying to get rid of that... this fan duct should make sure it's only sucking in air from abouve and blowing it out the bottom (now it feels like it's actually pushing air out on the left side of the intake lol)

print_settings.Notes:: I got the best results with the screen printed vertically. To ensure that it remained stable, I put down blue tape on the build plate and wiped the tape down with isopropyl alcohol immediately before the print. This provided excellent adhesion (so good, in fact, that I had to soak it in alcohol again afterwards to get the tape off the part). The rest of the parts were just printed on bare glass.

description.text:
The "Global Link" smartphone from the TV series Earth: Final Conflict (which aired 10 years before the first iPhone was released).

For best results with an FDM printer, it has been split up into sections which should be glued or epoxied together. This is not a "press print, wait for it finish, and you're done" model. Supports are strongly recommended.

This is a static open/closed version. I will eventually make a "hero" version with the accordion arm and roller-shade screen; I just need to obtain the right kind of spring before I can design the mechanism appropriately.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.12mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I got the best results with the screen printed vertically. To ensure that it remained stable, I put down blue tape on the build plate and wiped the tape down with isopropyl alcohol immediately before the print. This provided excellent adhesion (so good, in fact, that I had to soak it in alcohol again afterwards to get the tape off the part). The rest of the parts were just printed on bare glass.

Assembly diagram is included.

The whole thing was printed in 3Dom Ingeo PLA. Most of it was printed in white, and then sanded, primed, and then painted; the "power LED" was printed in natural PLA (translucent) and left unpainted; the belt clip was printed in black and left unpainted.

Vallejo Black (ribbed portion on the main case)
Vallejo Basalt Grey (handle, screen, outer bit on the main case part)
Vallejo Neutral Grey under Golden Iridescent Stainless Steel (main case, button)
Testors Gloss Black (camera lens, hat switch)
Behr "Sun Valley" interior house paint (screen)

Modeled in Blender, working from numerous screenshots from throughout the first season. I estimated a height of 6 inches (not including the camera housing).

If you'd like to print out a screen graphic for display, rather than using a green or blue screen for chromakey, I've included an overlay to composite over your photograph of choice and print, in both SVG and PNG (300 DPI) versions. Inkscape was used to create the graphic.

description.text:
The glovebox flashlight that comes with the E46 (and other) BMWs is underpowered and a little sad, but the 12v port in the glovebox is very convenient. I created a plug-in replacement for the flashlight that provides 2 3A USB ports.

Printed parts:

  1. Port head
  2. Plug part A
  3. Plug part B

Other parts:

  1. Pins from existing flashlight (doesn't need to be new. cheap)
  2. About 3" of 20 to 24 AWG or wire
  3. 2 USB 3A buck converter boards - from Amazon:
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XPZ7I4I/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Remember to solder the wires flat across the boards at a 90 degree angle to their long axis. The plug hits flush against the bottom of the boards and will interfere with the wires.

Printer:

Craftbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No supports required! Very clean print. Print with the usb port end face down, and with the two plugs flat on their large faces.

print_settings.Notes:: I'd suggest high infill and using an extra perimeter or two for the parts with nut-captures.

title: FolgerTech FT-5 X-Carriage (FT13, FT14, FT11, FT12)

description.text:
UPDATE 11/14: Motor mount screws lowered 1.5mm. In the original the top of the motor could rub the 2020 rail if you tightened everything just right.

UPDATE 11/7: It's been pointed out that the top piece is almost the exact width of the rail slider and if you tighten the bolts it can push pressure on the slider and bind. I've expanded the part by 2mm (1mm each direction) to hopefully ease that pressure.

Here are functional replacements for the FT-5 X-Carriage parts (FT13 - top/bottom spacer, FT11 - back face, FT12 - front face, FT14 - cable chain platform). I tried to solve three problems with the originals:

1) They are melamine. They tended to warp, loosen, and crack. Print replacements with high infill.

2) The holes on the FT14 were not counter-sunk and the FT14/FT13 combination was awkward. This replacement combines those parts and has a pedestal for the cable chain end - no bending or warping. It also has nut-captures for the nylock nuts that attach the cable chain.

3) You needed a wrench to tighten the long bolts holding the FT11 and FT12 together. This version has nut captures for those nylocks as well. You can tighten up your X-Carriage with only an allen wrench.

Additionally, these parts should be compatible with the factory parts and factory-compatible replacements. I am personally using the FT11, and FT13/14 replacement from this set along with the FT13 bottom and FT12 from this fan duct set (white parts in the images):

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1666994

Printer:

FT-5

Notes:

I'd suggest high infill and using an extra perimeter or two for the parts with nut-captures.

author: Moc

description.text:
After a horrible crash, I decided to cut off my bixlers nose and add a clip on gopro mount to use the fully protective cover rather than the not so protective mount I was previously using.
However you decide to attach this is your decision, I've posted instructions on what I've done which has worked for me but I cant guarantee the safety of your camera. The idea was initially inspired by this page but with a different approach (using the gopro clip instead of strapping the case on)
http://bixler2fpv.blogspot.com/
There will be improved iterations of this design in the future. I've included holes for m3 screws which can be used to attach the camera with a separate printed mount or with zip ties as is done in the link I've posted above.

I printed this with 2 shells and 50% infill to make it strong.  
I cut off the front of the nose informally (try to follow the picture to get the mount to match the diameter of the cutoff section)  
optional: make two holes on the sides to fill with glue and stick in two screws for extra strenght.  
Use gorilla glue (or any other strong glue you trust) on the cutoff face and place the gopro mount against it. I used tape to hold it down.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/47dpEQ0WLAC

title: Laser Cut Adjustable Mount for Mirror and Laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've made this to bounce laser on mirror to create a security field ;)

You will need M3 scew and bolt (I used 16mm length), and spring. You can look at the side diagram to see where the spring goes.

The idea, is by adjusting the M3 screw length, the mirror angle will change just a little, allowing to very precise laser bounce.

Total size should be 11.75 inches.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are recommended for the strap slots in the sides. You can do without them but it's a big gap and needs cleaning. I would try to angle the print so the supports in the strap slot make many small segments instead of one or two long pieces.

description.text: I wasn't planning to do anything for Halloween but I saw and got Slayaway Camp on Steam and had to make a Skullface mask. It's a bit of a WIP at the moment so I only have a photo of one of the more complete prototypes from my test fitting.

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

2014 Series 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports are recommended for the strap slots in the sides. You can do without them but it's a big gap and needs cleaning. I would try to angle the print so the supports in the strap slot make many small segments instead of one or two long pieces.

Adding the straps

Get either 2 inch wide elastic or 1 inch and double the straps. I included holes to stitch the straps to the model but super glue will work just fine. Make the straps short enough so the mask just touches your nose or nothing digs into your face. This will minimize the amount of cushioning needed to be added to stay in place.

Customizing the fit

I included some oblong inserts that can be glued to bits of foam or material to adjust the masks fit to your face. Use what you need to feel comfortable and be able to see.

Lens inserts

The lens inserts I'm printing out of red tGlase but anything will do. They are size for me so if you need to make your own the dimensions are:
60x40mm

You can model your own or just cut some from fabric, plastic,etc. If you decided to do something else I'd love to see it.

I made a notch in the corner to act as a key but went through so many design revisions it is only there due to lack of changing everything and wanting to move forward with the one-day-design costume.

Reference images

I played the game and looked at some of the media on the bluewizard page to get the design down.

Building and testing

I used Fusion 360 to design the parts and measured my face initially. After I had the basic design I made thin prints to test fits and form.

One thing that I really miss when parking my scooter is being able to gear it.
So i´ve made a simple handbrake for my Yamaha NMax.

I was made for a light-to-medium braking force, since it's not good for the braking components being under pressure for a long time.

If anyone needs a stronger braking power, just short the lenght for just 5mm and it´s going to be absolutely strong!

Never leave the brake pushed for long times (> week)!

It also fitted my other bike (Triumph Street Triple), but i think it would be useless to make a front tyre handbrake...

title: Pocket-Tactics: Core Set 5 (Fourth Edition)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CORE SET 5: Ghouls of Pnath against the Gugs of Koth

Happy Halloween, and welcome to the Fourth Edition of Pocket-Tactics, the modular, 3d-printable strategy board game that goes wherever you do!

This new edition represents years of streamlining, and we're excited to be ready to present this to you. These factions are pulled straight from the pages of H. P. Lovecraft's Dream Cycle stories (specifically The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath). Stay tuned for more sets and pieces, as well as updated rules for all of the previous edition's pieces.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

-------------------------------------------------RULES-------------------------------------------------------
For a standard core set, you'll want to print the following:
Creeping Ghoul x1, Feasting Ghoul x1, Fighting Ghoul x1, Priest of Mordiggian x1, Intrepid Dreamer x1, Charnel God x1, Gug Prisoner x1, Gug Sorcerer x1, Stonework tiles x9, Water tiles x3, Ruins x2, Tower of Koth x1

In addition, each player will need six dice (three red, and three blue).

Inverted-color images of the rules cards are available here, here. and here if you want something a little less ink-intensive.

SETTING UP

To begin, each player builds a force by selecting a number of units that total 50 points or less. For a larger game, you and your opponent could agree on a higher point total.

Next, each player chooses 6 tiles and all of the tiles are dropped into a bag and shuffled. Then, players agree (randomly, if you choose) on a “central feature” tile and then each choose a feature for themselves. (features are the 3-dimensional tiles such as Forest, Highlands, Villages, et cetera). Draw a single tile from the bag and place the central feature into that tile. Rolling off to see who goes first, players take turns drawing tiles from the bag and placing them adjacent to one another in whatever configuration they wish. Once all of the tiles have been placed, each player (in turn order decided by the roll-off) places their chosen feature so that it is both as many tiles away from the center and from one another as possible.

Once the map has been generated, players place up to three units of their choice (as many as they can fit) either in or adjacent to their chosen feature using the rolled-off turn order. You may only ever have a single unit occupy a tile or feature. Once this is finished, game play begins starting with the last player to place their units.

PLAYING THE GAME

Each turn, a player may either move one of their units, use one of their units to assault an enemy unit, or deploy a new unit onto the map.

MOVING: When activating a unit to move, they may do so into any unoccupied tile adjacent to them. If an allied unit is in an adjacent tile, the moving unit may “hop” over that unit to get to an open tile adjacent to their ally. A unit may only hop a single ally per move. Some features (Forests, Highlands, Villages, et cetera) have special movement considerations that will be listed on their rules card. Spaces that do not contain a tile may not be moved into.

SWIFT UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move.

FLYING UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move and may hop over enemy units as though they were allies when doing so.

ASSAULTS: When activating a unit to assault an adjacent enemy, each player tests their units Offense (OFF) by rolling their red dice and defense (DEF) by rolling their blue dice. A unit will have between zero and three of each kind of dice as shown on their rules cards. The assault occurs in three phases:

Roll Phase- All dice are rolled simultaneously.

Bump Phase- Some units have “bumps,” a numeric value with a + listed under either their OFF or DEF dice. Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player may take turns using a single bump. Each bump may adjust a single die result (either OFF or DEF) up by its value (though a single die may not go higher than 6). Some units may have multiple bump values listed under their dice or granted by special abilities or terrain effects.

Re-Roll Phase- Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player takes turns using any re-rolls they are afforded, either by special abilities or terrain/unit placement. Each re-roll allows the player to re-roll one of their die results (OFF or DEF). A unit that has adjacent allies is benefiting from “support” and gains one re-roll per ally. A unit also gains a single re-roll when occupying their “favored terrain” (a terrain tile or feature that is shown on their rules card).

Tally Phase- Each player checks their OFF results and checks them against the opponent's DEF results. Starting with the highest OFF die, compare it to the highest enemy DEF die. If the results are a tie, move on to the next highest. If a single OFF die can't be matched or beat by value from the enemy's DEF, that enemy is “defeated” and is removed from the map and placed in the victorious player's captures (a space to the side of the map on that player's side). If the OFF cannot beat the enemy DEF values, that unit is safe. Note that, because all dice are rolled at once, it is possible for both units to defeat one another simultaneously.

RANGED ATTACKS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may make assaults against units that are an extra number of tiles away equal to the numeric value listed to the side. Count through the closest route to get to the target before making a ranged assault. Features and enemy units block line of sight (except when a Flying unit is targeted or is making the assault) and empty spaces (spaces without a tile) always block line of sight. If a unit being assaulted is not capable of meeting the range requirements to the attacker, they may not roll their OFF dice for that assault.

DEPLOYMENT: In place of activating one of your units already on the map, you may choose a unit from your reserves (any of the units you didn't put on the map at the start of the game that haven't been captured by enemies) and place them adjacent to any feature on the map that you control (provided the space is unoccupied). If no such tile exists, you may not deploy a unit until one opens up.

Any player may, in place of performing a regular move action, move a piece into an occupied feature tile to return that unit to reserves. Similarly, a unit that is occupying a feature may move into that feature to return to reserves, though you then cede control of the feature by doing so.

TYPES

Listed directly beneath a unit's name are a number of “types” (Human, Elf, Robot, et cetera). These types have no effect on their own, though are referenced by certain abilities and terrain effects that may either be beneficial or detrimental to the unit.

HAZARDS

Some terrain tiles and features contain hazards. These are special effects that occur when a unit is moved into that tile. Units that are deployed into a tile with hazard effects ignore them, as do units that have that tile type as their favored terrain.

WATER: A unit moving into a Water tile must succeed at a DV 5 DEF test or be defeated immediately after doing so.

If a feature is placed in a terrain tile, the tile counts as that feature rather than the terrain type, and therefore negates any hazard effects native to the terrain type.

VICTORY CONDITIONS

A player achieves victory as soon as their opponent (or opponents) cannot activate or deploy any units. Alternately, victory is secured the moment any single player controls all features on the map.

This is an object I'm certain can help many teachers when teaching math. It is a number line. It comes with one main body and two extensions on each side (you don't have to print them off), it also  includes the attachments from 1-10 which you also can print off as many as you need. How to use it is in the instructions.  
When I was a kid I always had trouble with grasping the concept of integers. I couldn't understand that you could take away ten from two. And no matter how hard my teacher tried she couldn't get the majority of the class to comprehend subtracting negative numbers let alone multiplying and dividing. That is until our teacher started using number lines. A number line can be used by all math students. To young kids it teaches addition and subtraction; to slightly older kids it can teach multiplication and division; and finally to more advanced kids it can teach adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing integers. I believe this tool will help teachers substantially all through their years of teaching.  
The design can very easily be expanded to a number range much greater than the current -50 to +50 and I will work on it and have it up in a matter days. Then the upgrades just slide into the current extension. It is advanced yet straight forward leaves the field open for innovations and adjustments even though it is perfectly fine "out of the box".  
I'm very sorry for the bad pictures I couldn't get any good ones. I've also attached some work sheets to solve with the number line.

To 3d print just print it at 100% and whatever quality you want. It sounds very complicated but it really is very simple. Please look at the pictures for reference.
Here is how to use it: Addition:

  • Find the # closest to 0 in the equation and grab the attachment for it. eg. for -2+20 you would grab the "2" attachment

  • Put the left side (right side if the number closer to zero is negative ) of the attachment on the other number eg. for -2+20 you would put the right side of the attachment on twenty

  • Look at the opposite side of the attachment and there is your answer.
    • Subtraction:

  • Find the first number and grab the attachment for it. eg. for 6-4 you would grab the "6" attachment

  • Put the right side (left side if the number closer to zero is negative ) of the attachment on the other number eg. for 6-4 you would put the right side on 4

  • Look at the opposite side of the attachment and there is your answer.
    • Multiplication:

  • Choose either number and grab an attachment for it. Bigger usually works better.

  • Put the left side (right side if the number you chose is negative) on zero and take as many attachments as the other number and put them simultaneously next to each other. (go left if negative)
    • 3.Look at the opposite side of the attachment and there is your answer. Division:

  • Find the first number and grab the attachment for it. eg. for 6-4 you would grab the "6" attachment

  • Put the left side (right side if the other number is negative) on zero and put them simultaneously next to each other until you reach your second number. (go left if negative)

  • Count how many attachments it took to reach the second number (not the last one if it went over but count how much it went over by and that will be your remainder) and there is your answer.
    • I've also attached some work sheets to solve with the number line.

description.text:
I made this magnifying glass as pops for a Sherlock Holmes costume. The handle was printed in halves to avoid needing support. I printed in ABS with 10% infill. Then glued together. The outer ring is printed and glued to the handle. I added a thin piece of fresnel plastic lens then glued in the inner ring. This made it functional but light weight and safe enough a kid could not break it. Ipainted with acrylic art paint to mimic a wood and brass finish.

The fresnel material was just from Amazon and easily cut with scissors.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00P0B26OC

The Stealth Hawk antenna is one of the best performing omni directional antenna's ever designed. ota_canuck heavily optimized the design over at http://www.digitalhome.ca/forum/showpost.php?p=1149158&postcount=289. Simply print it, bend some wire (I used .130 dia solid coper wire), and enjoy HDTV with a boat load of channels. This antenna really is amazing. I've built 6 of them so far. This holder will keep the antenna's internal dimensions, and allow a balun (matching transforrmer) to be easily connected, and generally stiffen the antenna. If you build one, please post back your results.
Use solid .130 diameter wire, and add a balun.

Printer:

Anet A8 Prusai3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

*see notes

Infill:

*see notes

Notes:

All parts printed in PLA.

Frame:
Orientation: print with largest flat surface facing down.
Nozzle Size: .4mm
Layer Height: .2mm
Infil: 70%
Speed: 40mm/sec

Pen Cart and Clamp:
Orientation: print in the same orientation it will be used.
Nozzle Size: .4mm
Layer Height: .2mm
Infil: 70%
Speed: 40mm/sec

Spring:
Orientation: flat edge of spring facing down.
Nozzle Size: .4mm
Layer Height: .2mm
Infil: 50%
Speed: 20mm/sec

Putting it together

Other Parts
-LM8UU, Linear bearing , 2 ea.
-8mm Linear rod, 49mm long , 2 ea.
-M3 screw, 20mm long, 1 ea.
-M3 nut, 7 ea.
-Hobby Servo, I used a Dynam B2232
-Sparkfun servo trigger, 1 ea.
-4N36 Optocoupler, 1ea.

Assembly
To recess the M3 nuts into the plastic: Thread a M3 nut a few turns onto the end of a 20 mm screw. Heat the nut for a few seconds with a torch / lighter. While holding 20 mm screw press into the hex holes. ** once at desired depth quickly cool plastic with water.

Press in the LM8UU linear bearings into the pen cart. Use an 8 mm drill bit to correctly size the linear rod holes. Set the pen cart inside the frame. Press the linear rods through the bottom of the frame through the linear bearings then back into the frame.

For the remaining parts:
( use small drillbit to pre-drill, use small screws to attach components)

Mount your servo inside the top of the frame with the shaft facing left.
Mount the servo trigger wherever you choose. you may choose to mount it remotely and run servo wires to pen attachment.

Use the knob of your choice with the printed spring to connect to the pen cart.
** I recommend connecting the spring linkage only after powering up the servo trigger
and setting the servo positions.

comments.text:
Sadly, the Nikon part was too small for mine.
The actual bayonet part fitted fine, but the retention hole didn't come out far enough, causing the pin to just go around it..
comments.author: jelte1234

comments.text:
No problem with people using my designs or parts of them, that's why they're on Thingiverse. ;-)
However, two things should be pointed out: (1) you will not get infinity focus with your adapter and (2) translucent white is a really bad choice for the adapter material. Some filament colors are dark enough to not light leak, but even some blacks leak (especially in NIR); I've found that a couple of coats of flat black latex will create a good light seal, even filling any pinhole gaps in extrusion, but you need to keep the paint off any surfaces that are subject to mechanical wear because the paint can be scraped off by that.

print_settings.Notes:: UPDATE 3/14/17- I included a picture of the finished mini field my team made, and made it the default picture.  I recommend printing the whole center goal/center support/ center base at 1.25 of it's original scale, just to make the little pillars a little more robust.

title: FTC 2016-2017 Velocity Vortex Mini Model(Updated-Printable beacons)

description.text:
This is a miniature and printable version of the FTC field this year, Velocity Vortex.

I included some corner pieces to the field. We have 12 inch by 1 inch plexi-glass pieces that we are using to create a perimeter for the field by slipping them into the corner pieces. You could also use cardboard, or some other semi rigid material. Also worthy to note, we use a blue and red ball(two balls, one red, one blue) from an NXT kit for the cap balls. They are nearly the perfect size. We are also contemplating using ping pong balls, because of the lighter weight.

if you see team #8417 in competition(Lectric Legends, from KY), give us a shout!
If anyone has suggestions, comments, or anything, well.... comment with your suggestion, comments, or anything!
-Eric, Co-captain, Lead programmer, and one of four CAD specialists.

Printer:

Robo 3D R1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 except .2+ for corner goals

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

I did not make the entire field printable as solid piece, as the center goals would be much to small, and require support structure. I also did not make the beacons printable, for the same reasons. Not enough detail, and they are not worth messing with. I have now included beacons into the file, and they are printable

UPDATE 2/25/17- The beacons are now printable, and I have changed the orientation of the center goal base to allow for the goal to be more realistic.

UPDATE 3/9/17- The Center Goal Support was at a weird angle, making it difficult to rotate in Cura to be flat on the print bed. is fixed but may still require a 90 degree rotation depending on the software used.

UPDATE 3/14/17- I included a picture of the finished mini field my team made, and made it the default picture. I recommend printing the whole center goal/center support/ center base at 1.25 of it's original scale, just to make the little pillars a little more robust.

title: Normal distribution sliced to show "68-95-99.7 Rule"

description.text: One of the most important topics studied in probability and statistics is the Normal Distribution.  The outcomes of many natural phenomena follow the pattern of the Normal Distribution.  One property of a Normal Distribution is known as the "68-95-99.7 Rule".  This rule states that roughly 68% of the outcomes would occur within one standard deviation (higher or lower) of the center (also called the mean) of the distribution.  About 95% occur within two standard deviations or the mean, and 99.7% are within three standard deviations.  The Thing provided here allows students to explore the 68-95-99.7 Rule by cutting the Normal Distribution into pieces which are one standard-deviation wide.  Each piece is labeled with the approximate percentage of the outcomes which that piece represents.  The pieces can be combined in various ways and the proportion of the total outcomes can be obtained by adding the percentages together. The middle two pieces add up to 68%.  The middle four add up to 95%. If you add all six pieces together, it totals 99.7%.  Note: The pieces do NOT cover the remaining 0.3% (the highest or lowest 0.15%) because the Normal Distribution extends outward indefinitely, and is too long and thin to 3-D print effectively.  The pieces, as printed, are rotated and packed together to make a reasonably large version of the entire model printable at one time.

This Thing was designed using MasterCAM software, which is usually used to program numerically controlled mills and lathes. The original shape of the normal distribution curve was created using the equation y = exp(-0.5x^2) / sqrt(2 pi)

title: GoPro handle with O-rings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This GoPro handle is designed with o-rings and an opening for running a lanyard so you can more confidently film in various conditions. The model was designed to be printed with minimal support material. The inside is left hollow so you can minimize the material required as well as allow for adding attachments in the future to aid in filming. Photo credit to my sister.

Find out more about the GoPro handle here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PNeh97qzhh4

Footage shot with the handle in the ocean: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lpUUGmEYSws&t=19s
Footage shot with the handle around Los Angeles: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VGDnKi0Deo4&t=1s

I as designer assume no responsibility for the use and/or misuse of this item and any potential property damage this may cause.

External items required are:
GoPro compatible knob & nut
8, 3/4" ID, 7/8" OD, 1/16" Width O-rings
Super glue to hold the o-rings in place (optional)
After printing remove any supports if necessary. Also slide o-rings onto the handle and glue in place if you feel fit. Add a safety cable underneath if need be and your ready to go!

author: MakeItWithCalvin

description.text: Here's my first attempt at 3-d modeling.  The Banana slug is one of the most unusual creatures living in the Pacific Northwest (U.S.).  Since my transplant here a decade ago, I am still amazed at how big they can get - up to 8 inches.  I've made ceramic slugs and crocheted slugs, so a plastic one seemed like fun.

Be careful of the eye stalks, they can break off.  The slug in the photo has one eye stalk repaired with hot glue.  I modified the file to include a wider base for the eye stalks, but have not printed this version.  (I don't have a Makerbot, but I used one at Metrix Creat: Space in Seattle)
Note: Revised slug with thinner/neater optical stalks.  Cleaned up the mesh.

author: tbuser

description.text:
I did a frankenstein a while ago and
was never really happy with the work
(it was one of my first sculptris efforts)
This is more keeping with my current puppet head
sculpts.
Intended for a larger print, 0% infill 2 shells
with an expectation of some post printing cleanup.
The current workflow I have been using is to expect the prints
to be close to where they need to be, but need some work.
The trade off being less plastic and time used to print
and as the post printing processes give a very shiny surface,
the layer of slice can be somewhat coarse.
in short, if you use my print settings it will not pop off the FDM
build plate looking like a factory manufactured item.
you can use infill etc but my objective is a prototype, so it is more
an issue of getting close to what i need to where I can finish it
and at the same time save time and LOTS of material.
Tailor print setting to your own workflow and what you are looking to achieve.

this printed really nice without any holes or major rough spots at the settings 0% infill, 2 shells .27 slice 80 mm/sec speed.
color me surprised!
Acetone Vapor polished ABS

0% infill
2 shells
were my settings

description.text: A simple holder for 4x6 photos.

You will need to print
1x shaft
1x handle
2x washers
2x wheel
2x end support
2x side support
24x frame support, or alternatively you can use cut down wooden skewers.

You also need glue suitable for plastic
Paper
Paper glue
And of course, the printouts for each frame

To assemble:

  1. Glue the shaft to the two wheels. Make sure the wheels are the correct orientation so they will fit into the side supports.
  2. Place the washers over the external shaft of the wheels.
  3. Insert the wheels into the holes in the side supports.
  4. Glue the side supports into the top and bottom supports.
  5. Glue the handle into one of the wheels.
  6. Insert the spokes. These can be easily bent as they are inserted.

The last step is to print and cut your frames. These are based on 2x4" photos.
You can fold them in half around the spoke and hold them in place using a glue stick

Make sure you do a dry run first before glueing to ensure it all fits together.

More details at: http://failtryagain.jcroucher.com/2016/10/30/3d-printed-flip-book-machine/

Video: https://youtu.be/cAYadqMMgzA
Ball protective trailer

description.text: Here is a relief map of Mount Sinabung which had a recent spectacular explosion. The data comes from an Aster Global Dem, ASTGTM2_N03E098_dem.tif, which can be accessed via Earth Explorer - http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/ See thing:168477 Relief Map of Bora Bora for more details. Some have asked for more information about these relief maps and complete details are provided. A fortran program is included which directly outputs an stl file. The file was converted to its binary form; either netfabb Studio or MeshLab can be used, giving mount_sinabung.stl. The stl file was scaled and labeled with a simple openSCAD program to give mount_sinabung_labeled.stl.

Mount_sinabung_labeled.stl was printed directly on a Replicator build platform using 2 shells and 5% infill.  Mount_sinabung.stl is too large for the Replicator.  
The maps are 600 arc seconds on a side with a vertical scale of 200 meters per mm on a base of 3 mm.  The surface of the small lake to the north and slightly west of the volcano is approximately 1400 meters above sea level while Mount Sinabung is 2420 meters high.

Cloned from STL for future customization

Do not use clamps with square corners!
Rounded corners in twice stronger then square corners!

customize your own sizes in code

used libraries

title: Duet WiFi plus Duex expansion board enclosure

description.text:
This is a variant of my other Duet WiFi enclosure. This one will also take the Duet WiFi and the new Duex expansion boards in a single enclosure. It is untried because at the time of writing, the Duex expansion boards have not been released. It should work though.

The Duet WiFi and Duex expansion boards are designed to be fitted back to back. This enclosure design will accept then one above the other, as if they were joined at the Vin connector but then opened up like a book. The enclosure will accept two 80mm fans fitted internally which will blow air on to the back of he boards as is recommended. The fans exhaust through outlets in the top and bottom of the case.

There is room to run cables around the outside of the boards and of course, all the terminals on both boards will be easily accessible. I designed it to fit my printer with cables entering from the left and mounting holes in the base. The cable entry slots are shorter in the middle to allow for a ribbon cable to connect the two boards. there is a cut out in the top to allow easy access to the micro SD card and reset buttons.

I've included the OpenScad file so feel free to adapt it to suit your own needs.

Warning. This thing is 290mm x 140mm so will need a biggish printer bed. If your bed is smaller. then you could achieve the same result bu making two of my other enclosures and fitting them back to back.

Second Warning. You may need a longer Ribbon cable to join the two boards together.

title: Hanged spray can holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Got the idea from the Mostlighting's Spray can holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1436529).

I did not want to make holes on my wall or shelf for each holder, so I design a new one that can be hang.

You just need to use hooks at the begining on a top of a furniture (can be screwed if needed). Then can holder are chained width M3x10 screw and nuts (just screwed between each other, not on the wall/furniture).

I also add a basket to put little thing. A terminator can be used (this time screw are needed) at the bottom of the chain.

OpenSCAD sources are provided, so you can easly make can holder of the diameter you want.

I'm using a chain of more than a dozen of holder, used for weeks now, and it works great.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 Y-axis anti-slop guide plate

description.text:
I couldn't help but notice that the Y axis had 3 linear bearings on it not 4. It also looked like there was an opportunity for the Y axis to move around because of it.

I've created this plate in PET. It clips onto the Alu frame, locks the single bearing into place and provides two guides for the steel shaft. Clipping into the frame aligns everything. The spacing is such that it's about the same overall length as the bearings on the other side. It has clearance all round including space for missing the feet.

After clipping the plate in it's held in place by the zip-tie used to hold the bearing in place. You should apply a little light machine oil to the bearing shaft so that the guide runs cleanly.

There's a little bit of float built into the plate to compensate for alignment issues. The idea is to slow down the rate at which the Y axis can move around, not completely eliminate movement.

comments.text: Prusa actually switched — quite a while ago — from a 4 bearing to a 3 bearing Y axis deliberately. Nothing to do with cost, but solely because four bearings overconstrain the axis. The two bearings on the one side constrain both translational degrees of freedom (X and Z) plus two of the rotational ones. The other bearing only constrains the one remaining rotational degree of freedom, and the belt sets the Y position. By having two bearings, or by trying to constrain the one bearing too much, you get into problems when — not if — the two bars are very slightly non-parallel.
comments.author: JasperJ

comments.text: I did wonder why three not four and could see it wasn't a cost issue given quality of everything else. From what I could see bars should remain parallel once set.
comments.author: JasperJ

author: juanjo3d

title: Annotated Ideal Harmonic Transformer Math Manipulative

description.text:
Treat yourself and your classroom to a machine that shows you how Sine and Cosine relate to angles. There is an animation on my blog: http://swampcastle.blogspot.com/2013/11/harmonic-transformer-for-classroom.html I have also imported and assembled the models into OnShape, where you can take it for a virtual spin. Try it out; you won't be disappointed. About Onshape: http://swampcastle.blogspot.com/2015/08/onshape-shapes-up-great.html
Link to the model: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5c003295166a40c699e9ca02/w/8ec0747e1c854c81bd8468e9/e/b660adf4fde44b19baf860fa How to use:
Use the knob to rotate the arm to an angle. Read the value on the Sine and Cosine scales. Sine and Cosine values are given for a circle with a radius of 1, which is also called a "unit" circle. To obtain lengths for a circle with a radius other than one, multiply the reading from the machine by the desired radius. Sine and cosine are trigonometric functions of an angle, defined by using right triangles. In one of the figures, a right triangle has been drawn on top of the Harmonic Transformer. The angle is set to 30 degrees. The hypotenuse is the radius of the circle, shown as a green line. The radius is drawn from the arm's pivot center to the center of the knob, where the pin is. The blue horizontal line is the "adjacent" side of the triangle, and the magenta vertical line is the "opposite" side. Notice that the blue side is the same length as the reading on the cosine scale. Similarly, the magenta side is the same length as the reading on the sine scale.

Assembly instructions are provided with pictures and details at my blog: http://swampcastle.blogspot.com/2013/11/harmonic-transformer-for-classroom.html This is essentially my original Ideal Harmonic Transformer, with the addition of more labels. The labels make it easier to use, and are easier to read because the text is raised instead of cut-in.

NEW VERSION!!! POSTED 12-29-13
At first glance the updates are barely noticeable, but every piece has been revised. The changes make assembly easier with better fit and smoother operation. This Math manipulative is designed to appear playful from the first look. It lies flat on desk top, so it will also work well with overhead projection systems. Behind the mechanical fun there are several simple ratio exercises. The eight tooth "Idler" gear is supplied to add reverse rotation without affecting the ratios. Each interchangeable gear has built-in graphics to indicate the number of teeth as well as rotation position. Some gear ratio formulas can be found here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gear_ratio. Rubber bands provide tension to keep the wheels engaged no matter what the combination. FYI, the "T" on the gears stands for "teeth".

This thing is designed to print on MakerBot Replicator 2 machines, but I'm sure it will have good results on earlier machines as well. All parts fit within 105 mm x 105 mm build area. No support is needed.  
Assembly is simple, just look at the photos provided. The rubber bands are just 3/4" or 1" office supplies.  
One part that may get a little tricky is the Idler gear. That part is really two parts in one. In my test, it just needed to be broken loose and spun around a few times to free it up. The axle post is now a snap-fit into the center hole in the base unit so that it can be added or taken out as needed.  
Be sure to clean out the center holes in the gears after printing so that it is not too difficult to get them on and off of the pins  
Have fun learning!

title: Bracket for 3M Command Picture Hanging Strip

description.text:
Simple bracket sized for 3M Command Picture Hanging Strips. I've designed the for holding an LED strip under my bed, which had some 3M self-adhesive back side, but didn't hold strongly enough. Due to the nature of the 3M strips I can now also remove them again, if needed.

I recommend printing them with transparent filament so that they're almost invisible.

You can find those strips e.g. here: https://www.amazon.de/Command-17202-3M-Bilder-Montagestreifen-klein/dp/B00016ZLDY or here: https://www.amazon.com/Command-Picture-Hanging-Strips-8-Strips/dp/B00SFWNAFC/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1477825169&sr=8-5&keywords=command+picture+hanging+strips

author: xmbrst

title: Quanum Trifecta FPV Camera Mount for PZ0420m
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This board camera mount for the Hobbyking Quanum Trifecta was inspired by Chromebee's mount which he designed for a larger type of camera. In my opinion, the PZ0420m (and its derivates with enclosures) offers the best compromise for FPV, so this is the type I mostly use.

My design was started from scratch using "Inventor", if someone is interested in the raw-files, just let me know.

I exported variants with 0°, 5°, 10° and 15° of up-tilt, maybe there are some folks outside, who fly the trifecta a little faster :)

2016/12/11: Sorry, I only noticed by now, that I uploaded an older version of the 10° variant which was too narrow. Fixed that.

description.text:
This Z brace is designed as a drop-in replacement for the existing Z-axis top pieces. It allows a little extra clearance for the tops of the lead screws and bars so that they don't rub on anything.

It's designed so that the Z-axis can be bolted to a base plate to form a triangle. When used with the other Z-axis plates I've published here it allows the Z-axis to be "locked down" to create a more rigid machine.

I've used two 500mm M10 bars with nut traps and two adjustable nuts on each arm.

Josef Prusa's original STL was used as the starting point for the top pieces so that alignment was guaranteed.

For printing the feet are printed on their ends and the Z-braces on their sides. I've enclosed an STL that does this.

I've updated this to make the feet easier to fix and changed the top of the brace to be easier to adjust.

This is an ongoing experiment.

comments.text: Does this reduce the potential Z-axis maximum height at all ?
comments.author: WasteLandIndustries

comments.text: No
comments.author: WasteLandIndustries

comments.text: A move in the right direction to compensate a Prusa design weakness.  You should try to connect this threaded rod to the threaded rod making up the base.  Good point to have the whole machine solidly attached to a heavy thick multiplex board. Squareness of the machine has to be adjusted then. I use a 40mm table top as base. A concrete slab would be better but a bit overkill :)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I looked at linking to the M8 rods and decided against it.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Better make the whole machine rigid. The Prusa orange brace holding the original M8 plus smooth rod can be replaced by one connecting the Z M8.
True, usually high strength (10.8 and above) are black but I doubt they use that quality here.
Now, if everything is well secured to the heavy multiplex board, not just the Z M8 you added, it is OK too.
comments.author: Hanthony

comments.text: I checked the bars. Usually I can flex stock M8 threaded, but not these. Likewise the M10s show little flex under load so I think they are high strength not just surface coated stock.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I would really like to see the Z tied to the frame. The Z is not perpendicular to the XY bed and I'd love to adjust it and lock it down. But, I also want to make sure that I can use Hofftari's vibration dampeners to reduce noise and resonance from the table below.
comments.author: Hanthony

comments.text: There are some braces on Thingiverse that do bolt to the M8s.
comments.author: rutilate

title: Monoprice Select Mini - Bed Attached Camera Mount For Time-Lapse!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To learn more about this and our other prints, please visit http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well check out our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIy3DTech.com to learn more about 3D Printing, CNC Machining, and CO2 Laser cutting & engraving! Also if you are looking for maker swag be sure to check out http://Swag.DIY3Dtech.com for one of a kind Maker Swag! Also to find out more about how we designed, printed and installed this, check out our video here: https://youtu.be/BvNYB0FQgws

This is a bed mounted camera adapter plate for the Monoprice Select Mini which was designed in Open-SCAD. The bolt holes where aligned with my unit and assume (since I have only one that they are uniform between machines. In addition, the hols are made slightly over-sized to allow for variances in printing and easy of assembly. Will need however four (4) M3 bolts 20mm long to replace the existing shorter bolts as well as four (4) M3 flat washers. You reuse the four (4) existing lock washers placing them between the the bolt head and the M3 flat washer. If the holes are little off or undersized for you particular printer, simply use a drill to ream them out larger as required. In addition I have included the Open-SCAD source code here (http://openscad.diy3dtech.com/open-scad-designing-and-3d-printing-a-bed-mounted-camera-adapter-for-the-monoprice-select-mini/ ) so you can modify it if you wish.

Printer:

Any 200mm x 200mm printer will work

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25

Notes:

Flip over to print and that is about it and please don't fr get to like and follow us on Thinigiverse and for info on Open-SCAD check out our site http://OpenSCAD.DIY3DTech.com for the complete source code to this and other projects!

comments.text: One problem, the currently shipping units don't use two screws on the face for each rail.  Now there's just one going straight in the rod.  The bed still has the four holes, they haven't changed the sheetmetal stamping.  But there's nothing behind the two other holes.
comments.author: wkearney99

comments.text: I should also point out that since this was too big to print on the mini, I used a local 3Dhub for the service. I believe it was around $10 and the item turned out fantastic.  Seems a lot better made than I'd get out of my Mini.  But then he's using a $2k Lulzbot, compared to my $200 Mini.
comments.author: wkearney99

comments.text: I have a mount that prints on the mini and clips on without screws, but I modeled it around the old style bed as well, so I don't know how well it would fit on your machine. There is a remix that includes a tab that fits onto the old screws, but it hasn't been remixed for the new screws, so maybe if you or someone you know is good at modeling it could be fixed :D
comments.author: wkearney99

description.text: Another 3D Scan of my son Monty Timic Ozar sleeping. Scanned with my new Sense 3D Scanner by 3DS!

comments.text: Most of you might know me when I worked for MakerBot, now I'm making AWESOME at 3DS!!!!  If you want an affordable, easy to use 3D Scanner then Sense is for you.   I've been using it with the Surface Pro 2 and it's fun to scan outdoors.  The tracking works great and the software has amazing editing features that makes clean up easy.  Save your scan for print in both STL and full color PLY.
comments.author: OZAR

comments.text: I also have a Sense 3D Scanner on the way ... are you happy with the results ? is it all they say it is ?
comments.author: PauloAmaral

comments.text: Wow, that looks excellent.  How do you like the scanner?  It's beyond reasonable at $399 if it works well.  I have a nextengine 3d scanner that cost a lot more (Almost ten times the cost!).  It does excellent scans, but it's slow and bulky.  To do large scans it takes forever because you have to mount it on a tripod and scan the object from 6.5" (For excellent detail) to 18" (Decent detail) away.  Imagine how long it would take to scan something large with only scans that are that far from the object, you have to mark it with clay and move it around, it takes FOREVER.  This new scanner must be FAST to be able to capture your child sleeping like that.  He'd wake up and start screaming if he saw a nextengine attached to a scary looking tripod with lasers shooting out at him and all the noise it makes.  But so would any grown man  :)   Does this thing scan as fast as a cell phone takes a picture?  Or does it need to be stationary for long time while it scans?
comments.author: falken76

comments.text: Ozar, since 3d systems does not allow returns, I wanted your opinion on whether you are happy with it so far and would buy again.  I have been using a Kinect with Recontructme.
comments.author: MakerBeck

description.text:
I saw the Rubik's Companion Cube "Stickers" by twisteddream13 and thought that the design would make a great trinket box.
I have taken inspiration from the design and recreated it as a solid side. Print it out 6 times and glue 5 of them together along the bevelled edges. Leave the "lid" loose and you have a handy dandy companion cube box for all your secret stuff.

description.text: A first of a set of some planned minor upgrades for my Opiliones 2L Delta printer, is this filament guide for the 2,85mm filament.

Printer:

Velleman Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50% - but using less is no problem

Notes:

Although intended to be mounted on the Opiliones 2L, I printed this part of the Vertex K8400 - as the big delta was working on a large print. :-)

When printing on the side, with support - the guide groove will pick up some minor deformation from the support material: make sure to sand this away, to reduce friction to the max.

When properly sanded, there should be no noticeable friction from the filament into the guide groove.

Mount with 2-sided sticky tape & 2 tie rips.

comments.text: If you want to reduce friction for a filament guide, there is about only one product that fits the bill while being common, PTFE ! Any "guide" that doesn't use it (or an equivalent material) is worthless.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I respectfully disagree. I've worked with PTFE & carbon filled PTFE for over 30 years.: PTFE is an excellent bearing material, I'll agree to that.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: About everybody in the 3D world has PTFE tube lying around, easy enough to accommodate it in a printed part. My filament rides on PTFE in guide, extruder ... till the entrance of a full metal hot end.
comments.author: Harry_D60

comments.text: Nice, good to read your design is working for you.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Your choice, just that people reading this have to be warned.
To include a piece of PTFE tube in a filament guide is easy and costs nothing.
comments.author: Harry_D60

The dimensions are small and tight tolerances,If u don't have a very precise printer u need to scale the file + 10% and fixed contact with a bit of glue.If u have a very precise machine you need a 0,2-0,25mm nozzle and a very clean filament. It's all, good job!

PS very important,I forgot to specify that the scale of the object to be x10.
Is an incorrect setting in the conversion of inventor when I export the file in STL. I seek the problem and solve it as soon as possible

remixed_from.author: sasa
remixed_from.title: Simple rack and pinion code for reusing in other projects

description.text: Please use this updated version instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:200895

I'm moving FAST on this design. I've made a number of improvements and you're probably better off waiting a few days while I finish up working on the design. Check out my blog for more on this and other drawing robots (including more instructions, etc) http://plotterbot.com and the Robot Hacks (https://plus.google.com/communities/114867980170611537174) page for the latest pics and development. Recent change NOT included in these files:
Added an actually useful Y stage rack
Added a crappy pen holder (soon to be less crappy)
Many parts now interlock for a better fit To learn more about this project, check out this blog post: http://plotterbot.com/2013/11/an-itty-bitty-drawing-robot/ This is a VERY (very, very, very) beta version of a tiny CNC robot. I wouldn't suggest playing along at home unless you're really interested in getting your hands dirty. I've included a MakerWare file with all the parts on a single plate to fit a Replicator 1. This is the very first version I've tried to print and I can already see lots of room for improvement. However, it is extremely cheap to build (estimated $50 - which includes the cost of a $30 Arduino Uno) http://plotterbot.com/2013/11/tiny-cnc-drawing-robot-cost-estimate/ Right now all it does is run the basic Arduino servo "sweep" sketch which isn't that impressive. However, I'm planning to add a better Y stage so it can hold a pen and, hopefully, start drawing small pictures. I'm using a slight variation on Sasa's rack and pinion OpenSCAD code. I've made some minor changes to their code and included the variation here. This project was inspired by the Make Robot Hacks project (https://plus.google.com/communities/114867980170611537174) and the Piccolo tiny CNC robot by Diatom studio (http://www.piccolo.cc/). A video of the robot in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GPAihIzBYKE

Right now there are only six parts. I'm trying to design this 'bot to be fairly easy to hand assemble quickly. Briefly, you would build it as follows:
1) Place the large base (Xrack014.stl) on a flat surface
2) Insert a servo motor into the X stage motor mount (Xmotormount014.stl)
3) Put the X pinion onto the X stage servo (Xgear014.stl)
4) Put the X stage motor mount with pinion into the base
5) Put a servo motor into the Y stage motor mount (Ymotormount014.stl)
6) Put the Y pinion onto the Y stage servo (Ygear014.stl)
7) Put the Y stage motor mount with pinion onto the X stage
8) Place the Y axis rack between the Y pinion and the X stage motor mount Done!

title: "Universal" jigsaw piece, connects with itself on every side

description.text:
[edit]Done with this. Check the remix, the new interlocking tile. Not universal anymore, though.

This is a first attempt at a blank jigsaw piece that can connect at every side to copies of itself.

The intended use is for scrabble - locking pieces mean they won't get scrambled so easy. Hence the interlocking parts at all sides.

Naturally it shouldn't be used on its own - would be rather boring :-D

I tried to find something like it, but didn't find anything. Either it doesn't exist or I fail at searching...

[edit] One problem just popped up - apparently it's not possible to connect four pieces into a square...

I knew there's something I didn't see :-D

Well, that's why it's tagged Work in Progress.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

anything goes, it's not really detailed

Notes:

I've finally had some success printing two tiles at the same time.
It's not perfect, but I think it's doable. Certainly saves a lot of time :-D

But be careful and check the tiles after each print. They're small, so it's easy for something to get stuck and ruin the interlock.

Layer height doesn't really matter - it's straight up, I've successfully printed with 0.3 .

Nozzle size, however, probably is important - I'm printing with .4 and while I would love to try the .6 nozzle, I think it'll ruin the measurements - I've printed too many already to switch now.

The placeholder - no outside connectors, but TOP connectors that emulate the sides of other tiles

As the picture shows - the placeholder can be put between other tiles, and offers a grip to a further tile that can be placed on top.

It's not ideal, it's not very pretty, but it works.

I'm open for suggestions, though.

comments.text:
I was looking for ways to build bigger objects by using simpler basic building blocks. But it also had to have strength when interlocked. In my specific case I wanted to make a large desk organizer tray for my son.
I printed four of the locks at 3 times their size using ABS with a .5 hotend (Lulzbot Taz 5). They do hold up strong when interlocked and will be stronger still when used with ABS "glue". However, as the creator noted, you can't put 4 together in a square. I am certain that you can print the pieces "in place" but I wouldn't be able to lock them together for my bigger object. I thought it was a good try for a start though.
comments.author: sirwejiv

author: Rejutka

description.text:
Scanned on Next Engine this is one part of a multi-part sculpture by artist Holly Holmes. Typically she makes 100+ of these forms in ceramic and stacks / piles them as needed. We will be exprimenting with using 3d modeling to create new forms - otherwise impossible / very difficult to make in traditional ceramic sculpture.
http://hollyholmes.info
Print. Stack. Pile. Make with different colors. Send photos to [email protected]

We've all seen various incarnations of weighted companion cubes from Portal, but I thought it would be nice if the cube was a little more than a dead weight. I offer here my take on a more loveable cube, the laser cut Lighted Companion Cube.   
The lighted companion cube is completely portable, and gives many hours of light from a set of six standard rechargeable AA NiMH cells tucked away in his over-crowded interior. He has ambient and radiant modules. The radiant side is an array of 25 white LEDs, arranged in four concentric zones (1 x 1 LED and 3 x 8 LEDs) that can be controlled separately. With all four zones on it is very bright! His ambient module consists of a number of RGB (red, green, blue) LEDs. Each color can be controlled separately, allowing the user to set any possible color to reflect/complement their present mood.  
The ambient side is also controlled by a charge/discharge circuit. Pressing the Charge button charges an internal 10,000 uF capacitor, which in turn drives a series of transistors to power the mood light. Over time the capacitor will discharge though, dimming the mood light and eventually switching off the light entirely. The light will gently fade away and automatically switch itself off, saving its battery power for many successive uses.

Just note that I would consider this a bit of a WIP as, while I have made one, I have only made one and the design/files have not been highly refined through successive builds. I've tried to put everything I could think of in the file though. If anyone is crazy enough to want to make one, I'm willing to offer whatever advice I can to help. The design was made from various thicknesses and colors of recycled acrylic. It was made with these colors/thicknesses because that is what I had and what my local plastics recycler had in industry offcuts. It's best to test fit things as you go. I assembled the individual side/panels first, complete with LEDs and controls installed. I also put black tape around both light panels, to stop any bleeding that might happen through the rest of the box sides. This did mean I had to dremel off some of the plastic of the top panel handle recess to allow the tape to fit.
I soldered the electronics
into a piece of perforated MDF. The perforated design is in the file, and fits between the zone lighting switches once the box is assembled. I wrapped the circuit board in cereal box cardboard to insulate/protect it and to stop it moving around. The capacitor goes underneath the mood light, and the battery pack slips neatly down the space left in the middle. You want a 2 X 3 battery pack to fit neatly in the space provided (obviously a long 1 x 6 flat pack will not fit). I placed a small piece of foam on the batteries before closing the bottom twist-lock access panel, to cushion the battery and keep it firmly in place. I sourced all my components cheaply from ebay. My transistor selection was based largely on what I had in my little hobby box. The white LEDs should be the straw hat type. This is so they mount in the panel without the need to stick through. Only the flat pinned panel sections on mine have been glued. The rest have been push-fit only. The interlocking corner design makes sure they cannot come apart. I would recommend blackening the ends of the tabs on the mirror box where they insert into the front panel. I didn't on mine, and you can see some light leakage through the white panel.

comments.text: jdlrios: Just let me know what you need to know. I must mention that I am thinking of replacing the current circuit with a simple (555) timer based circuit. I've just got to figure out how to create a timer that can completely turn itself off at the end of the cycle. Maybe an SCR or something. The problem with the current circuit is that the color of the light changes as the light slowly fades out/voltage drops. The color change is most evident when setting the light to pink, which combines the blue (high voltage drop LED) and red (low voltage drop LED). Pink being the signature color of companion cubes, I'm starting the think it should stay the exact pink you set it.

description.text:
These are the 3D printed part designs that go with my Instructable, Making Your Mini Laser Engraver Safer And Better. They are designed to be used with any of the SuperCarver-style "Laser Engraver Printer Cutter Carver DIY Engraving Machine" units commonly sold for between $80 and $150, and I have applied them to a 1000mW @ 405nm unit branded HTPOW. See the after and before photos above. Here is a video from the webcam I placed inside the engraver -- it is not sped-up; this is the actual engrave speed.

These machines have the potential to very quickly cause significant harm. I'm not an expert in the law, nor in laser safety; I'm just a maker who sees the potential, both good and bad, of these little engravers. You bear all responsibility for safe configuration and operation of your laser. I'm just describing what I did to my machine in an attempt to reduce the risk and improve functionality.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

These parts are easy to print, but material choice is very important. Print them in PLA. Why? PLA behaves much better than most plastics when hit by a laser; especially avoid any chlorinated plastics, but also avoid ABS because the gas produced if it gets hit by the laser is pretty nasty. The color of the material also matters; enclosure parts need to be opaque to the laser light, and the jigs should be made of a color that minimizes scattering of the laser light.

Read my Instructable to understand how these 3D-printed parts are intended to be used; also read other materials so that you can understand the dangers and safely operate your laser. Avoid the temptation to try things first and read instructions after a serious problem has surfaced: I didn't even plug-in my laser's power supply until after I had built an enclosure for the unit.

These parts were all designed using OpenSCAD. I might post a Customizer version once I'm sure the design will not change for a while -- for example, I'm still looking at alternative methods to make the vent filtering more effective.

description.text:
This is my own design of the Fidget Cube.
Parts list:
6xTactile switch - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10-100-pieces-lot-6-6-7-SMD-tact-switch-6x6x7mm-SMT-micro-Black-button/32714736875.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.Z1VfaQ

1xSteel ball bearing - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/High-precision-G16-0-002mm-Stiffiness-62-Bearing-Steel-13mm-Antiacid-corrosion-resisting-bearing-ball/32343119889.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.Z1VfaQ

1xJoystick - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2016-Hot-Sale-New-3D-Analog-Button-for-PSP-2000-Joystick-Console-Stick-Repair-Moduel-Replacement/32675523519.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.Z1VfaQ

1xBearing 4x13x5mm - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10PCS-LOT-624-624Z-624ZZ-ball-bearing-4-13-5-mm-4x13x5mm-chrome-steel-bearing/1831141476.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.Z1VfaQ

1xSmall rocker switch - you need this type https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Original-new-100-Taiwan-deliwei-imported-miniature-gold-pin-switch-toggle-switch-rocker-switch-type-2/32733294071.html?spm=2114.01010208.3.49.8rbQhh&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_2_422,searchweb201603_1&btsid=e6dc3a60-5879-4834-a3c2-b898dd7b49fd
the plastic handle need to be removed

1 mm steal rod (see in the pictures)

The sixth tactile switch is located inside the ball holder

Important - glue the tactile switchs + "buttons" in their place first, and after that glue the "ball holder" (and remember to locate the sixth tactile switch and the steel ball bearing inside the 'ball holder" before gluing it)

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100% on the small parts, 25% on the body

Notes:

All the parts were printed with PLA.
Print Body1 with a brim.
Body1 and Body2 were printed with 25% infill, rest of the parts were printed at 100% infill.

  • One-to-one printable, but can also be adapted to any size.
  • For better printing can also insert a chamfer at the corners.
  • For Bricks >10x10 you need a long time for calculation in Fusion 360.

Please combine all elements before you exporting the stl file.

I tested the brick with 3 slicer:
Cura
Slic3r
Simplify3d

http://www.kinder-technik.de/3d-druck-slicer-test-mit-lego/

title: M6 Funnel Bolt - MK8 Extruder Filament Guide

description.text:
Edit: Just noticed the scaling may have been off on either one or both of the 4 and 7 mm bolt STL files. If you downloaded the v02 STLs, please get the v03 models instead. I also added an STL with both the 4 and 7 mm bolts for those wanting to print both at once (for whatever reasons).

An M6 bolt with a funnel shaped hole in it. I made it as a sort of filament tip guide for Anycubic's Metal MK8 Extruder Kit (see photo). It makes threading filament into my printer's bowden tube much less of a struggle. Note the photo is of the "right hand" version of the kit.

If you are still using the stock extruder, try my M6 Nut Funnel Cover - Exruder Filament Guide.

Notes

There are 2 versions, one with 4mm of thread and one with 7mm of thread. Installing the 7mm version will require removing the extruder base plate from the top of the printer (if installed). I made the 4mm version because I had already installed the base plate and didn't want to remove it to install the guide bolt. Installing the 4mm bolt without removing the plate is a little tricky, but it can be done.

This was designed this for use with 1.75mm filaments, it will not work with 2.5 or 3 mm filaments (the hole diameter is close to 2.55mm). Should be printable without supports, I recommend using a small layer height to preserve the threads (I used 0.1mm).

Support for moto-reductor Modelcraft, used on robot projects (http://www.conrad.fr/ce/fr/product/227552/Motorducteur-150-Modelcraft) Screws :
  • M3x6 for the motor (V3) or flat head M3x8 (V4)
  • M4 for the support
    • NEW on the V4 !
  • use flat head screws (M3x8 max) for the motor (ideal for to use this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1162070 for the wheel)
  • "puzzle part" end to align two motors (an extension will come)
  • small improvment under the support.
    • Feel free to improve this model yourself, or let me know your ideas for improvement!
    Have a nice print ;)
