title: Anet A8 Filament Guide and more

description.text:
This was one of the first add-ons I designed and printed for my Anet A8 3D printer. Foremost I saw how the filament was shaving on the extruder. With this part the filament now goes straight through the center of extruder filament hole. I decide just to make a small hole to achieve the least friction on the filament.
The part also holds the cable of the heat element and both fans. In my case it also holds the cable of the proximity sensor.
I've also included a slot in the center support to hold the cable of the extruder cooling fan.

Update 31.12.2016: I've removed the cable holder portion for those that don't need it and added it to the files for download.

Please let me know if you have a problem with the design so I can improve it if necessary.

Also please post a picture with comments if you have made one.

Thanks.

Leo

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The part was printed at 40mm/s with a 0.8mm shell thickness and 0.8mm top / bottom thick closures.

The "Supports" is recommended for the slot in the support for the cooling fan cable.

print_settings.Notes:: This was designed to print vertically, and requires a machine with at least 210mm vertical build height (the size of my machine's Z-axis). Use a brim or the design incorporating "adhesion pads" to ensure the part sticks to your build platform. KEEP THE MASS OF THE VEHICLE LESS THAN ~40g. This means printing with 1 perimeter and less than 20% infill.

description.text: This project was inspired by a project our class did in Design and Model back in 2013. A "skimmer" is a simple ground-effects vehicle shaped like an airfoil which creates enough lift to "hover" above the ground as it travels forward. Feel free to put your classroom 3D printer to use to demo this model!

remixed_from.title: "Universal" jigsaw piece, connects with itself on every side

description.text:
Based upon my (unfinished) "universal" jigsaw tile, these tiles contain the klingon letters in a romanized font.

I may add klingon glyphs later, but for now I want to see if the design actually is usable. It takes far too long to print them right now :-(
(About 5-8 minutes per tile, and I'm not sure I can print more than 1 or 2 at the same time...)

I'm not sure if the design will stay - I'm considering embossing the letters instead of having them come out of the tile, and of course the "jigsaw" piece itself needs work. Currently it's not possible to create a circle of tiles, which seriously limits your options. Not sure how to circumvent that.

The "placeholder tile" is a workaround - it has no outside connectors and emulates those on top, so you can put another tile on it. But it's a crude method.

Still, as long as it works - and I'm out of time, in 2 days the qepHom starts and I want to have my scrabble set then :-D

Number of tiles to play

This is the number list I've been given at the qepHom where I got the klingon scrabble set:
(it's always number : tiles; the points are only on the tiles, sorry)

10 : a '
08 : I e
06 : o u
05 : H j m
04 : D v
03 : l ("el", not "eye")
02 : b ch gh n p q S t w y
01 : Q r tlh ng

New tileset in work.

I've finally found a design that works better, I hope to upload it soon. It'll be a remix of this.

description.text: a simple cube for travel and fidgeting - now pocket sized!

Assembly is very simple. Just print out 4 cubies, 1 of each core, and a pin. Depending on your printer's quality, you may need to file the cores a little bit. Insert the pin into the tapered core, and put all the cubies on both cores. Apply glue to the end of the peg, and insert it into the other assembly. let dry, and enjoy!

UPDATE:
glue one of the cubies to one of the cores to prevent the cube from getting stuck.
This cube was based off if a mix of adrbot's 1x2x2, and my limit cube. It was optimized to be printed small, and does so even on my not- too- accurate replicator 1.

description.text:
Ok so I want to build a Mame Cabinet,
So Ive got the software working...sort of,
Now I need some buttons....Ahh print some. I have used switches out of a washing machine control panel, simply because I have lots of them, I would have used microswitches but I only had enough for a joystick.. thats another project..

Print one of each: button, case, switchholder Clean up edge's if required, make sure the button moves freely inside the case. insert switch, make sure it is firmly seated in the holder otherwise it will sit up too high and be on all the time. Holding the case upsidedown drop the button in, then slip the switchholder assembly in and turn to lock in place.
You could put a drop of glue in to stop it poping out, however I have found that they hold in quite nicely...so far.. Carefully solder your wires on to the switch terminals. You should be good to go.. I have included the Scad file (Still learning this scad stuff so it needs some polishing, i know, but it works for me).
If you have a different switch just alter the switchholder and location slots to suit yourself..

comments.text: Thanks, sorry I never got round to design the joystick.
comments.author: nilcosta

comments.text:
Hi!
Can you tell me the dimensions of microbutton?
I think 1212Height?
comments.author: Jvan

comments.text:
Hello Jvan,
The button is 11.9x11.9mm square and the housing is 3.4mm high with the button circle another 0.9mm on top of that.
comments.author: Jvan

comments.text:
Thanks!
So 12x12x4.3mm tactile button :)
comments.author: bobwomble

comments.text:
That sounds right, I salvaged mine from an old washing machine control board.
Like most of my projects, including my printer, I re use whatever I can get my hands on.
comments.author: Jvan

comments.text: Hi there, do you use any springs for this? I printed buttons a few days ago - they touched the micro-buttons but hadn't enough space to come back to top...so I had to use springs between those two...
comments.author: killi

comments.text:
Hi there killi, sorry for the delay, been workin long hours.
No I dont use any springs at all, just rely on the microswitch spring.
On my ones, when assembled, there is a very small gap between the switch and the bottom of the button.
I have found that the switch has to be well seated in the holder or it will sit to high and the button will always be on.
comments.author: killi

comments.text: I built a mame cabinet or two in the pass, and ended up buying all the push buttons...
comments.author: dpms808

comments.text:
Thanks, I tend to make as much as I can, sometimes I spend more $$ making stuff than buying, but its way more fun.
Ive also made a joystick that seems to be working well, I will post info on that soon, just go some more testing to do.
comments.author: dpms808

My son loves Pokemon cards and lately we have been making our own. He is 6 and was getting frustrated by his cards being so different (dimensions, etc.,)...so 3d printing to the rescue.

We used the actual Pokemon card dimensions and built this template for easy tracing. We may also make some templates for the Breaks, trainers, and energies...

He requested we print some for all his friends and figured we would share if anyone else wanted to create your own Pokemon cards

Happy Building
